solutions.author: Human
solutions.solution:
Such a sequence does exist.
Let $p_{1}<p_{2}<p_{3}<\ldots$ be the usual list of primes, and $q_{1}<q_{2}<\ldots, r_{1}<r_{2}<\ldots$ be disjoint sequences of primes greater than $2018^{2018}$. For example, let $q_{i} \equiv 1$ and $r_{i} \equiv 3$ modulo 4. Then, if $n=p_{1}^{\alpha_{1}} p_{2}^{\alpha_{2}} \ldots$, where all but finitely many of the $\alpha_{i}$ will be zero, set

$$
b_{n}:=q_{1}^{\alpha_{1}} q_{2}^{\alpha_{2}} \cdots, \quad \text { for all } n \geqslant 2
$$

This sequence satisfies requirement (iii), but not the ordering conditions (i) and (ii). Iteratively, take $a_{1}=r_{1}$, then given $a_{1}, \ldots, a_{n-1}$, define $a_{n}$ by multiplying $b_{n}$ by as large a power of $r_{n}$ as necessary in order to ensure $a_{n}>a_{n-1}$. Thus $d\left(a_{m}, a_{n}\right)=d\left(b_{m}, b_{n}\right)=$ $d(m, n)$, and so all three requirements are satisfied.

grading_scheme.title: Correctness
grading_scheme.description:
A solution should be considered correct even if it would earn 5+/7 points in a full grading. Examples of small penalties worth 1 point are if the solution:

  • Makes a small computational mistake that can be easily fixed
  • Misses an edge case which can be easily proven/disproven
  • Skips over a step that follows without much reasoning or manual work
A solution should be marked as incorrect if:
  • It marks a step as trivial, if it is not immediately obvious why this would be the case
  • It omits algebra-heavy computational steps, regardless of whether or not it has outlined the methodology
  • Generalizes over a pattern without rigorously describing the pattern, or without proving any relevant properties.
  • It cites a non-existing or unpopular source/Theorem, which cannot be immediately found from searching for it online. Thus, any theorems that can be immediately found and have a Wikipedia article are allowed.
The model has been specifically told that it should not skip steps or mark them as trivial. Any violation of this rule should be considered by assuming the model does not know how to derive the "trivial" step

attempts.solution:
Yes, such a sequence exists. We will construct such a sequence \((a_n)\).

First, let's analyze the given conditions.
Let \(P(k)\) denote the set of distinct prime factors of an integer \(k\). Then \(d(m,n) = |P(m) \cap P(n)|\). The condition (iii) is \(|P(m) \cap P(n)| = |P(a_m) \cap P(a_n)|\) for all \(m \neq n\).

1.  Consider \(m=1\). For any \(n>1\), \(P(1) = \emptyset\). So \(d(1,n) = |P(1) \cap P(n)| = |\emptyset| = 0\).
    Thus, for the condition (iii) to hold, we must have \(d(a_1, a_n) = 0\) for all \(n>1\). This means \(P(a_1) \cap P(a_n) = \emptyset\) for all \(n>1\).

2.  Condition (i) states \(a_1 \ge 2018^{2018}\). This implies \(a_1 > 1\), so \(P(a_1) \neq \emptyset\).

3.  Consider the case \(a_k = a_{k+1}\) for some \(k \ge 1\).
    Then \(P(a_k) = P(a_{k+1})\), so \(d(a_k, a_{k+1}) = |P(a_k) \cap P(a_{k+1})| = |P(a_k)|\).
    By condition (iii), we must have \(d(k, k+1) = |P(a_k)|\).
    Since \(k\) and \(k+1\) are consecutive integers, they are coprime, i.e., \(\gcd(k, k+1)=1\). This means \(P(k) \cap P(k+1) = \emptyset\), so \(d(k, k+1)=0\).
    Therefore, \(|P(a_k)|=0\). The only positive integer \(x\) for which \(P(x)=\emptyset\) is \(x=1\). So \(a_k=1\).
    If \(a_k=1\), then by condition (ii) (\(a_m \le a_n\) for \(m \le n\)), we must have \(a_1 \le a_k = 1\). So \(a_1=1\).
    This contradicts condition (i) (\(a_1 \ge 2018^{2018}\)).
    Thus, \(a_k \neq a_{k+1}\) for all \(k \ge 1\).
    Combined with condition (ii), this means the sequence \((a_n)\) must be strictly increasing: \(a_1 < a_2 < a_3 < \dots\).

Now we construct the sequence \((a_n)\).

Let \(\mathbb{P} = \{p_1, p_2, p_3, \dots\}\) be the set of all prime numbers, where \(p_k\) is the \(k\)-th prime number (so \(p_1=2, p_2=3, \dots\)).
We partition \(\mathbb{P}\) into three disjoint infinite sets \(Q_A, Q_B, Q_C\). For example:
\(Q_A = \{p_{3k-2} : k \ge 1\} = \{p_1, p_4, p_7, \dots\} = \{2, 7, 17, \dots\}\)
\(Q_B = \{p_{3k-1} : k \ge 1\} = \{p_2, p_5, p_8, \dots\} = \{3, 11, 19, \dots\}\)
\(Q_C = \{p_{3k} : k \ge 1\} = \{p_3, p_6, p_9, \dots\} = \{5, 13, 23, \dots\}\)
These three sets are disjoint, their union is \(\mathbb{P}\), and each is infinite.

Step 1: Define \(a_1\).
Let \(x_0\) be the smallest prime in \(Q_A\). In our example, \(x_0 = p_1 = 2\).
Let \(K\) be a positive integer such that \(x_0^K \ge 2018^{2018}\). Such \(K\) exists, for example \(K = \lceil 2018 \log_{x_0} (2018) \rceil\).
Define \(a_1 = x_0^K\). Then \(P(a_1) = \{x_0\}\). This satisfies condition (i).

Step 2: Define auxiliary primes.
Let \(f: \mathbb{P} \to Q_B\) be a bijection. Such a bijection exists because \(\mathbb{P}\) and \(Q_B\) are both countably infinite. For each prime \(p \in \mathbb{P}\), let \(x_p = f(p)\). These primes \(x_p\) are distinct elements of \(Q_B\). For example, we can set \(x_{p_k} = p_{3k-1}\) for \(k \ge 1\). Then \(x_2 = x_{p_1} = p_2 = 3\), \(x_3 = x_{p_2} = p_5 = 11\), and so on.
Let \(Q_C = \{r_1, r_2, r_3, \dots\}\), where \(r_j\) are the primes in \(Q_C\) listed in increasing order. In our example, \(r_1=p_3=5, r_2=p_6=13, r_3=p_9=23, \dots\).

Step 3: Construct \(a_n\) for \(n \ge 2\) inductively.
For \(n \ge 2\), let \(P(n) = \{q \in \mathbb{P} \mid q \text{ divides } n\}\) be the set of distinct prime factors of \(n\).
Define \(S_n = \prod_{q \in P(n)} x_q\). If \(P(n)\) is empty (which only happens for \(n=1\), not for \(n \ge 2\)), \(S_n=1\). Since \(n \ge 2\), \(P(n)\) is never empty.
We choose \(y_n \in Q_C\) for each \(n \ge 2\) as follows:
For \(n=2\): Let \(y_2\) be the smallest prime in \(Q_C\) (i.e. \(r_1\)) such that \(y_2 \cdot S_2 > a_1\). Such \(y_2\) exists because \(S_2 \ge 1\), and \(Q_C\) is an infinite set of primes, so its elements are unbounded. Set \(a_2 = y_2 \cdot S_2\).
For \(n > 2\): Let \(y_n\) be the smallest prime in \(Q_C \setminus \{y_2, y_3, \dots, y_{n-1}\}\) such that \(y_n \cdot S_n > a_{n-1}\). Such \(y_n\) exists because \(S_n \ge 1\), and \(Q_C \setminus \{y_2, y_3, \dots, y_{n-1}\}\) is an infinite (hence unbounded) set of primes. Set \(a_n = y_n \cdot S_n\).

By this construction, \(a_1 < a_2 < a_3 < \dots\). Thus, condition (ii) (\(a_m \le a_n\) for \(m \le n\)) is satisfied (in fact, it's strict inequality).

Step 4: Verify condition (iii).
The set of prime factors of \(a_1\) is \(P(a_1) = \{x_0\}\) (since \(a_1 = x_0^K\)).
For \(n \ge 2\), \(a_n = y_n \cdot S_n = y_n \cdot \prod_{q \in P(n)} x_q\). Since \(y_n \in Q_C\) and each \(x_q \in Q_B\), and \(Q_B, Q_C\) are disjoint, \(y_n\) is not equal to any \(x_q\). Also, all \(x_q\) are distinct for distinct \(q\). Thus, \(P(a_n) = \{y_n\} \cup \{x_q \mid q \in P(n)\}\).

The primes \(x_0 \in Q_A\), \(x_q \in Q_B\) (for \(q \in \mathbb{P}\)), and \(y_n \in Q_C\) (for \(n \ge 2\)) are all distinct because \(Q_A, Q_B, Q_C\) are disjoint sets, the map \(f\) is a bijection (so \(x_q\) are distinct for distinct \(q\)), and \(y_n\) are chosen to be distinct at each step.

We need to check \(d(m,n) = d(a_m, a_n)\) for all \(m \neq n\).
Case 1: \(m=1, n>1\).
\(d(1,n) = |P(1) \cap P(n)| = |\emptyset \cap P(n)| = 0\).
\(d(a_1, a_n) = |P(a_1) \cap P(a_n)| = |\{x_0\} \cap (\{y_n\} \cup \{x_q \mid q \in P(n)\})|\).
Since \(x_0 \in Q_A\), \(y_n \in Q_C\), and \(x_q \in Q_B\), and these sets are disjoint, the intersection \(\{x_0\} \cap (\{y_n\} \cup \{x_q \mid q \in P(n)\})\) is empty.
So, \(d(a_1, a_n) = 0\). Condition (iii) holds for this case.

Case 2: \(m, n > 1, m \neq n\).
\(d(m,n) = |P(m) \cap P(n)|\).
\(P(a_m) = \{y_m\} \cup \{x_q \mid q \in P(m)\}\).
\(P(a_n) = \{y_n\} \cup \{x_r \mid r \in P(n)\}\).
The intersection \(P(a_m) \cap P(a_n)\) is:
\( (\{y_m\} \cup \{x_q \mid q \in P(m)\}) \cap (\{y_n\} \cup \{x_r \mid r \in P(n)\}) \).
Since \(m \neq n\), \(y_m \neq y_n\).
The primes \(y_k\) are in \(Q_C\) and primes \(x_s\) are in \(Q_B\). Since \(Q_B\) and \(Q_C\) are disjoint, \(y_k \neq x_s\) for any \(k,s\).
Therefore, the intersection is \( \{x_s \mid s \in P(m)\} \cap \{x_s \mid s \in P(n)\} \).
This simplifies to \( \{x_s \mid s \in P(m) \cap P(n)\} \).
The cardinality of this set is \(|P(m) \cap P(n)|\), because \(x_s = f(s)\) and \(f\) is a bijection, so distinct primes \(s\) map to distinct primes \(x_s\).
Thus, \(d(a_m, a_n) = |P(m) \cap P(n)| = d(m,n)\). Condition (iii) holds for this case.

All three conditions are satisfied by the constructed sequence \((a_n)\).
(i) \(a_1 = x_0^K \ge 2018^{2018}\) is satisfied by choice of \(K\).
(ii) \(a_m < a_n\) for \(m < n\) is satisfied by construction. This implies \(a_m \le a_n\) for \(m \le n\).
(iii) \(d(m,n) = d(a_m,a_n)\) for \(m \neq n\) is satisfied as shown above.

Therefore, such a sequence exists.

Final check of an example for \(a_n\), \(n \ge 2\):
Let \(x_0=2\). Let \(K\) be large, e.g., \(2018^{2018} < 2^K\). Then \(a_1 = 2^K\).
Using the example partition and bijections:
\(x_2=3, x_3=11, x_5=19, \dots\)
\(Q_C=\{5,13,23,31,\dots\}\).
\(P(2)=\{2\}\), so \(S_2=x_2=3\). Choose \(y_2 \in \{5,13,23,\dots\}\) such that \(y_2 \cdot 3 > a_1\). Let \(y_2\) be the smallest such prime. \(a_2 = y_2 \cdot 3\).
\(P(3)=\{3\}\), so \(S_3=x_3=11\). Choose \(y_3 \in Q_C \setminus \{y_2\}\) such that \(y_3 \cdot 11 > a_2\). Let \(y_3\) be the smallest such prime. \(a_3 = y_3 \cdot 11\).
\(P(4)=\{2\}\), so \(S_4=x_2=3\). Choose \(y_4 \in Q_C \setminus \{y_2, y_3\}\) such that \(y_4 \cdot 3 > a_3\). Let \(y_4\) be the smallest such prime. \(a_4 = y_4 \cdot 3\).
\(P(6)=\{2,3\}\), so \(S_6=x_2 x_3 = 3 \cdot 11 = 33\). Choose \(y_6 \in Q_C \setminus \{y_2,y_3,y_4,y_5\}\) such that \(y_6 \cdot 33 > a_5\). Let \(y_6\) be the smallest such prime. \(a_6 = y_6 \cdot 33\).

Let's check \(d(2,4)\) and \(d(a_2,a_4)\).
\(d(2,4) = |P(2) \cap P(4)| = |\{2\} \cap \{2\}| = 1\).
\(P(a_2) = \{y_2, x_2\}\). \(P(a_4) = \{y_4, x_2\}\).
Since \(y_2 \neq y_4\) (they are chosen at different steps from \(Q_C\)), and \(y_k \neq x_2\) (since \(y_k \in Q_C, x_2 \in Q_B\)).
\(P(a_2) \cap P(a_4) = \{x_2\}\). So \(d(a_2, a_4) = |\{x_2\}| = 1\). This matches.

Let's check \(d(2,3)\) and \(d(a_2,a_3)\).
\(d(2,3) = |P(2) \cap P(3)| = |\{2\} \cap \{3\}| = 0\).
\(P(a_2) = \{y_2, x_2\}\). \(P(a_3) = \{y_3, x_3\}\).
Intersection is empty because \(y_2 \neq y_3\), \(x_2 \neq x_3\), and \(y_k \neq x_j\). So \(d(a_2, a_3)=0\). This matches.

The construction is valid.

The final answer is $\boxed{Yes}$.

result.summary: The proof constructs the desired sequence by partitioning the set of all primes into three disjoint infinite subsets Q_A, Q_B, Q_C. It picks a₁ as a sufficiently large power of the smallest prime in Q_A to satisfy (i). It then fixes a bijection f from all primes to Q_B and, for each n≥2, encodes the prime factors of n via the product S_n=∏_{q|n}f(q). Next it chooses a fresh prime y_n from Q_C to ensure a_n=y_n⋅S_n exceeds a_{n−1}, giving a strictly increasing sequence satisfying (ii). Finally it checks that any common prime factor between a_m and a_n exactly corresponds to a common prime factor of m and n, so d(a_m,a_n)=d(m,n), satisfying (iii).

attempts.solution:
Answer.  Yes, such a sequence exists.

Throughout the proof the word “prime’’ always means “prime number’’ and
“distinct prime’’ means “prime counted without multiplicity’’;  
for a positive integer \(x\) the set of distinct primes that divide \(x\)
is denoted by \(\mathcal P(x)\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  Choosing the first term \(a_{1}\)

Let \(p_{1}=2<p_{2}=3<p_{3}=5<\dots\) be the primes in their natural order
and let  

\[
t=\min\Bigl\{k\in\mathbb N :\; p_{1}p_{2}\dotsm p_{k}\ge 2018^{\,2018}\Bigr\}.
\]

Put  

\[
a_{1}=p_{1}p_{2}\dotsm p_{t}.
\]

Because the product of the first \(k\) primes tends to infinity with \(k\),
such a \(t\) exists and by construction  

\[
a_{1}\ge 2018^{\,2018},
\]

so requirement (i) is satisfied.

For later use set  

\[
R=\{p_{1},p_{2},\dots ,p_{t}\}=\mathcal P(a_{1}).
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  A reserve of new primes  

Since only the primes in \(R\) have been used so far, all primes larger
than \(p_{t}\) are still free.  
List them again in increasing order

\[
q_{1}=p_{t+1},\;q_{2}=p_{t+2},\;q_{3}=p_{t+3},\ldots .
\]

Define an injective map  

\[
\varphi:\{\text{all primes}\}\longrightarrow
\{q_{1},q_{2},q_{3},\ldots \}\,(=\mathbb P\setminus R)
\quad\text{by}\quad
\varphi(p_{j})=q_{j}\;\;(j=1,2,3,\dots ).
\]

That is,
\(\varphi\) sends the \(j\)-th prime to the \(j\)-th unused prime.
Because the image of \(\varphi\) is disjoint from \(R\),
no prime that divides \(a_{1}\) will ever divide any other term of our
sequence.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  Constructing the remaining terms

We define \(a_{2},a_{3},\dots\) inductively.
Assume that \(a_{1},a_{2},\dots ,a_{n-1}\) have already been fixed
(for \(n\ge 2\)).
Write the prime factorisation of \(n\) as  

\[
n=p_{1}^{\alpha_{1}}p_{2}^{\alpha_{2}}\dotsm p_{s}^{\alpha_{s}}
\qquad(\alpha_{i}\ge 1,\;p_{i}\text{ distinct}).
\]

Step A.   Base of \(a_{n}\).
Let  

\[
B_{n}= \prod_{i=1}^{s}\varphi(p_{i}).
\]
Clearly \(B_{n}\ge 2\) and all its prime factors lie outside \(R\).

Step B.   Choosing a (large) exponent.
Because \(B_{n}\ge 2\), we can pick a positive integer exponent \(e_{n}\)
so large that  

\[
B_{n}^{\,e_{n}}>a_{n-1}.     \tag{1}
\]

(For instance, any \(e_{n}>\log_{2}a_{n-1}\) will do.)

Step C.   Definition of \(a_{n}\).
Put  

\[
a_{n}=B_{n}^{\,e_{n}}
      =\prod_{i=1}^{s}\varphi(p_{i})^{\,e_{n}} .
\]

This completes the inductive step and therefore the definition of the
whole sequence \((a_{k})_{k\ge 1}\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Verification of the three requirements

(i)   Already checked in Section 1.

(ii)  Monotonicity.
By construction (1) we have \(a_{n}>a_{n-1}\) for every \(n\ge 2\);
hence \(a_{m}\le a_{n}\) whenever \(m\le n\).

(iii)  Preservation of the number of common distinct primes.

•  First note that for \(n\ge 2\)

\[
\mathcal P(a_{n})=\{\varphi(p)\;:\;p\in\mathcal P(n)\}
\quad\text{and}\quad
\mathcal P(a_{1})=R,
\]

and \(\varphi\) is injective with image disjoint from \(R\).

•  If one of the indices equals \(1\),
say \(m=1<n\),
then \(\mathcal P(a_{1})\cap\mathcal P(a_{n})=\varnothing\),
so \(d(a_{1},a_{n})=0=d(1,n)\).

•  For two indices \(m,n\ge 2\) we have  

\[
\mathcal P(a_{m})\cap\mathcal P(a_{n})
     =\{\varphi(p)\;:\;p\in\mathcal P(m)\cap\mathcal P(n)\},
\]

and because \(\varphi\) is injective,

\[
d(a_{m},a_{n})
   =|\mathcal P(a_{m})\cap\mathcal P(a_{n})|
   =|\mathcal P(m)\cap\mathcal P(n)|
   =d(m,n).
\]

Hence (iii) is satisfied in every case.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
5.  Conclusion

The sequence \((a_{n})_{n\ge 1}\) constructed in Sections 1–3 fulfils
conditions (i), (ii) and (iii).  
Therefore such a sequence does indeed exist. ∎

result.summary: The proof first picks a₁ as the product of the first t primes so that a₁≥2018^{2018}. It then lists all larger primes q₁,q₂,… and defines an injective map φ sending the jth prime p_j to q_j. For n≥2, it factors n into distinct primes, sets Bₙ=∏_{p∣n}φ(p), chooses eₙ large enough that Bₙ^{eₙ}>a_{n−1}, and defines aₙ=Bₙ^{eₙ}. By construction aₙ is strictly increasing and the distinct primes dividing aₙ are exactly φ(primes dividing n), so d(a_m,a_n)=d(m,n).

To determine whether there exists a sequence $(a_n)$ of positive integers satisfying the following conditions:

1. $a_1 \geq 2018^{2018}$,
2. $a_m \leq a_n$ whenever $m \leq n$,
3. $d(m, n) = d(a_m, a_n)$ for all $m \neq n$,

we must ensure that the number of distinct primes dividing both $m$ and $n$ is the same as the number of distinct primes dividing both $a_m$ and $a_n$. This is a strong structural condition on the sequence $(a_n)$, and we must construct it carefully.

---

### Key Observations

- The function $d(m, n)$ counts the number of **distinct** primes dividing both $m$

result.summary: The proof restates the goal of constructing a non-decreasing sequence \((a_n)\) satisfying \(d(m,n)=d(a_m,a_n)\) and notes that \(d(m,n)\) counts distinct common prime divisors, but it stops after these observations without providing any construction or verification of the required conditions.

issues.description: The proof is incomplete, ending abruptly without providing the sequence construction or any further argument.
No explicit definition of \(a_n\) is given, so the proof fails to demonstrate how to construct the required sequence.
The proof does not address condition (i) \(a_1 \ge 2018^{2018}\) nor ensure the monotonicity condition (ii) \(a_m \le a_n\).
There is no verification that the undetermined sequence satisfies \(d(m,n)=d(a_m,a_n)\).

attempts.solution:
To determine if there exists a sequence \((a_n)\) of positive integers satisfying the given conditions, we construct such a sequence. The conditions are:

1. \(a_1 \geqslant 2018^{2018}\),
2. \(a_m \leqslant a_n\) whenever \(m \leqslant n\),
3. \(d(m, n) = d(a_m, a_n)\) for all positive integers \(m \neq n\), where \(d(m, n)\) is the number of distinct prime divisors of \(\gcd(m, n)\).

Recall that \(d(m, n) = |P_m \cap P_n|\), where \(P_k\) is the set of distinct prime factors of \(k\). Similarly, for the sequence \((a_n)\), define \(Q_n\) as the set of distinct prime factors of \(a_n\), so \(d(a_m, a_n) = |Q_m \cap Q_n|\).

The goal is to define sets \(Q_n\) and then assign values \(a_n\) with prime factors exactly \(Q_n\), such that:
- \(|Q_m \cap Q_n| = |P_m \cap P_n|\) for all \(m \neq n\),
- The sequence \(a_n\) is non-decreasing and \(a_1 \geqslant 2018^{2018}\).

### Step 1: Defining the sets \(Q_n\)

For each positive integer \(n\), let \(S_n = P_n\) be the set of distinct prime factors of \(n\). Note that \(S_1 = \emptyset\) since 1 has no prime factors.

Define the sets \(Q_n\) as follows:
- For \(n = 1\), choose \(Q_1\) to be a non-empty finite set of primes. Specifically, let \(Q_1 = \{p_1\}\) for some prime \(p_1\). This set must be disjoint from all other \(Q_n\) for \(n > 1\) to satisfy the intersection conditions.
- For \(n > 1\), define \(Q_n\) using a bijection on the primes. Let \(g\) be a bijection from the set of all primes to a set of primes disjoint from \(Q_1\). Then, set \(Q_n = g(S_n) = \{g(p) \mid p \in S_n\}\).

This construction ensures that:
- For \(m \neq n\) both greater than 1, \(|Q_m \cap Q_n| = |g(S_m) \cap g(S_n)| = |g(S_m \cap S_n)| = |S_m \cap S_n|\) since \(g\) is a bijection.
- For \(m = 1\) and \(n > 1\), \(|Q_1 \cap Q_n| = 0\) because \(Q_1\) is disjoint from all \(Q_n\) for \(n > 1\), and \(d(1, n) = |S_1 \cap S_n| = 0\).
- The sets are well-defined, and the pairwise intersection sizes match \(d(m, n)\) for all \(m \neq n\).

### Step 2: Assigning values \(a_n\) with prime factors \(Q_n\)

Each \(a_n\) is a positive integer whose distinct prime factors are exactly \(Q_n\). Assign exponents to the primes in \(Q_n\) to form \(a_n\). Specifically, for each \(n\), and for each prime \(q \in Q_n\), assign a positive integer exponent \(e_{n,q}\), and set:
\[
a_n = \prod_{q \in Q_n} q^{e_{n,q}}.
\]
The exponents are chosen to make the sequence strictly increasing (and thus non-decreasing) and to satisfy \(a_1 \geqslant 2018^{2018}\).

The sequence is constructed inductively, ensuring \(a_n > a_{n-1}\) for all \(n \geqslant 2\), and \(a_1 \geqslant 2018^{2018}\).

- **Base case (\(n = 1\)):** Set \(a_1 = p_1^{e_1}\) where \(p_1\) is the prime in \(Q_1\). Choose \(e_1\) such that \(a_1 \geqslant 2018^{2018}\). Since \(p_1 \geqslant 2\), we can choose \(e_1\) large enough; for example, \(e_1 = \lceil \log_{2}(2018^{2018}) \rceil\) suffices, but any sufficiently large \(e_1\) works as \(p_1^{e_1}\) grows without bound.

- **Inductive step (\(n \geqslant 2\)):** Assume \(a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_{n-1}\) have been defined with \(a_1 \geqslant 2018^{2018}\) and \(a_1 < a_2 < \cdots < a_{n-1}\). Define \(a_n\) as follows:
  - The set \(Q_n\) is fixed and non-empty (since \(n \geqslant 2\) has at least one prime factor).
  - Set \(a_n = \prod_{q \in Q_n} q^{e_{n,q}}\) for some positive integer exponents \(e_{n,q}\) to be chosen.
  - Since \(Q_n\) is non-empty and contains at least one prime \(q \geqslant 2\), the product \(\prod_{q \in Q_n} q^{e_{n,q}}\) can be made arbitrarily large by increasing the exponents \(e_{n,q}\).
  - Choose the exponents \(e_{n,q}\) large enough so that \(a_n > a_{n-1}\). Specifically, since \(a_{n-1}\) is fixed, and the minimal value of the product with minimal exponents is at least 2, but can be increased beyond \(a_{n-1}\) by choosing sufficiently large exponents.

This choice is always possible because:
- The set \(Q_n\) is finite and non-empty.
- Increasing any exponent increases the product.
- The product can exceed any fixed bound (in this case, \(a_{n-1}\)) by making at least one exponent sufficiently large.

result.summary: The proof constructs for each positive integer n a set Qₙ of primes by mapping the distinct prime factors of n via a bijection g onto a new pool of primes disjoint from Q₁. It then defines aₙ as the product of the primes in Qₙ raised to suitably large exponents chosen inductively so that a₁≥2018^{2018} and a₁<a₂<⋯. The bijection ensures |Qₘ∩Qₙ|=|Pₘ∩Pₙ|, giving d(aₘ,aₙ)=d(m,n), while the exponent choices guarantee the required ordering and initial bound.

issues.text: Let g be a bijection from the set of all primes to a set of primes disjoint from Q₁.
issues.description: The proof asserts the existence of such a bijection without providing any construction or justification, relying on a cardinality argument about infinite sets that is not elaborated.

issues.text: Choose the exponents e_{n,q} large enough so that aₙ>a_{n-1}.
issues.description: The argument glosses over how to select the exponents concretely to ensure the strict inequality, offering no explicit bound or algorithm for these choices.
It claims without justification that a bijection preserves intersections via g(A)∩g(B)=g(A∩B); while true for injective maps, this property is not explained or cited.

The proof is largely non‐constructive, relying on unspecified existential choices of both the bijection g and the exponents e_{n,q} without giving explicit constructions, which may be insufficient for a fully rigorous solution at the intended level.

attempts.solution:
Proof. We shall construct explicitly a non‐decreasing sequence of positive integers \((a_n)_{n\ge1}\) satisfying (i)–(iii).  

1.  Enumeration of the “coding” primes.  Let  
\[
p_1=2<p_2=3<p_3=5<\cdots
\]
be the increasing sequence of all primes.  Define an injective map  
\[
f\colon\{p_i\}_{i\ge1}\longrightarrow\{p_i\}_{i\ge1},
\qquad
f(p_i)=p_{2i}.
\]
Thus \(\mathrm{Im}(f)=\{p_2,p_4,p_6,\dots\}\) is an infinite subset of the primes, and its complement  
\[
T\;=\;\{\,p_{2i-1}:i=1,2,3,\dots\}
\]
is also infinite.

2.  Definition of the “base‐part” \(L_n\).  For each integer \(n\ge1\), write its prime factorization
\[
n=\prod_{i\colon p_i\mid n}p_i^{e_i}, 
\]
and set
\[
L_n \;=\;\prod_{p_i\mid n}f(p_i)
\;=\;\prod_{i\colon p_i\mid n}p_{2i}.
\]
By convention, if \(n=1\) (so it has no prime divisors) then the product is empty and we set \(L_1=1\).

3.  Inductive choice of “padding” primes \(r_n\).  We shall choose primes
\[
r_1,r_2,r_3,\dots\in T
\]
inductively so that
\begin{itemize}
  \item[(a)] the primes \(r_n\) are all distinct,
  \item[(b)] \(r_1\ge2018^{2018}\),
  \item[(c)] for \(n>1\), one has 
    \[
      r_n\;\ge\;\Bigl\lceil \frac{a_{n-1}}{L_n}\Bigr\rceil,
    \]
    where \(a_{n-1}\) has already been defined.
\end{itemize}
At the \(n\)th step the forbidden primes are those in the finite set
\(\mathrm{Im}(f)\cup\{r_1,\dots,r_{n-1}\}\), but \(T\) is infinite, so there are infinitely many primes in \(T\) outside that finite set.  Moreover for any integer \(M\) there exists a prime \(>M\).  Hence we can choose \(r_n\in T\setminus(\mathrm{Im}(f)\cup\{r_1,\dots,r_{n-1}\})\) so large that (b),(c) hold.

4.  Definition of \(a_n\).  Having chosen \(r_n\), set
\[
a_n \;=\; L_n\;\cdot\;r_n.
\]
We check the three required properties:

(i)  Since \(L_1=1\) and \(r_1\ge2018^{2018}\), we have
\[
a_1 \;=\; L_1\,r_1 \;=\; r_1\;\ge\;2018^{2018}.
\]

(ii)  For \(n>1\), by (c) we have
\[
r_n \;\ge\;\frac{a_{n-1}}{L_n},
\]
hence
\[
a_n \;=\;L_n\,r_n \;\ge\; L_n\;\frac{a_{n-1}}{L_n}
\;=\;a_{n-1}.
\]
Thus \(a_1\le a_2\le a_3\le\cdots\), and in particular \(a_m\le a_n\) whenever \(m\le n\).

(iii)  Finally we show that for \(m\neq n\),
\(
d(a_m,a_n)=d(m,n).
\)
Observe that the prime divisors of
\[
a_k \;=\;L_k\;r_k
\]
are exactly
\[
\{\,r_k\}\;\cup\;\bigl\{\,f(p)\;:\;p\mid k\bigr\}.
\]
Since \(r_m\neq r_n\) and each \(r_k\notin\mathrm{Im}(f)\), any common prime divisor of \(a_m\) and \(a_n\) must lie in \(\mathrm{Im}(f)\).  Moreover
\[
f(p)\;\big|\;a_m,a_n
\quad\Longleftrightarrow\quad
p\mid m\text{ and }p\mid n
\quad\Longleftrightarrow\quad
p\mid\gcd(m,n).
\]
Hence the set of common prime divisors of \(a_m,a_n\) is
\[
\bigl\{\,f(p):p\mid\gcd(m,n)\bigr\},
\]
and so its cardinality is exactly the number of distinct primes dividing \(\gcd(m,n)\), namely \(d(m,n)\).  Thus
\[
d(a_m,a_n)
\;=\;
\bigl|\{f(p):p\mid\gcd(m,n)\}\bigr|
\;=\;
\bigl|\{p:p\mid\gcd(m,n)\}\bigr|
\;=\;
d(m,n).
\]

All three conditions (i), (ii), (iii) are therefore satisfied.  This completes the construction of the desired sequence \((a_n)\).  ▢

result.summary: The proof constructs a non‐decreasing sequence aₙ by first encoding the prime divisors of n via an injective map f(p_i)=p_{2i} to form Lₙ=∏_{p|n}f(p), then choosing distinct 'padding' primes rₙ from the complementary odd‐indexed primes so that rₙ≥⌈a_{n−1}/Lₙ⌉ and r₁≥2018^{2018}. Setting aₙ=Lₙ·rₙ ensures a₁≥2018^{2018}, the sequence is non‐decreasing, and d(a_m,a_n)=d(m,n) since the only common prime factors of a_m and a_n are the images f(p) of the primes dividing gcd(m,n).
